@michaelhipke8394 I mean seeing who comes across 1st is the entire point of a race.  It wouldn’t matter as much if some one else could win a race and at least compete in the points.  But yes most people watch racing to see who wins the race, not who was the best of the people who lost.  That’s what a race is to see who the fastest is.  The winner is the fastest, the end.  Doesn’t matter what the people behind the fastest did, they’re not the fastest, which is the point of a race. 

Are there still battles for position?  Sure.  But battling is just a process of them trying to be the fastest, but the simple fact is none of the ones battling are battling to be the fastest.  Which again being the fastest is the entire point of racing, but they’re not even battling to be the fastest.  They’re battling just so they didn’t lose by the worst time at that point.  It’s like saying hey I lost but at least I didn’t lose by 20 seconds like you did.  That’s literally all it means

@Truthbomb918   Yes, they can lose that much weight. They lose MUCH more than that. A set of hards is 44kg in pure rubber, not including the rims. 3kg is nothing. That's only 7% of the rubber. They even gain 1kg just in 1 lap by weaving during the cooldown lap.

To put 0.1kg in perspective, that's half the weight of a Big Mac. I'm sure when you're smearing 100c rubber across a 7km track, you're losing more than half a burger in weight. I used it as a low example to show how such a small thing can make a difference.

1: It's up to the stewards. I would imagine not, as the penalty was just for track limits rather than any form of endangerment and so doesn't require a strict punishment.

2: Max got a 10s penalty for the contact, I would suspect the stewards thinking would be that this covered all his incidents.
Also note that "moving under braking" is not a real rule. People always talk like it is one but it's actually just "driving erratically or in a way that is potentially dangerous".
So stuff like this is very much up to the stewards rather than being a clear, strict rule that would guarantee a penalty.

3: Track limits IS treated as a clear & pretty strict rule nowadays - doesn't matter whether you're gaining or losing time, if you go off the track too often by yourself you get a penalty.

Not sure how F1 judge these matters - I'm a bike racing fan and the rules there are quite simple - although bikes tend not to lock wheels (and survive) like cars do. From every angle I have seen MV was on the inside of the corner and ahead of LH at the time of the incident - this is called a "block pass". Even though MV locked up, and as a result ran deep, he has track position in that corner and it should be LH responsibility to adjust his line - yielding the corner if necessary to avoid the collision. If MV ran so deep/wide that he forced LH off track on the outside I'd blame MV, and maybe we'll never know, but IMO LH should have yielded as he was on the outside and behind.

@nathanstone2635  My dude. You don't overtake anyone in any form of motorsports without disparity in performance... With slower vehicles, it's the slipstream, with series that have a greater disparity of driver skill (F2 and 90s F1), it's due to mistakes. 

Generally speaking, it takes a significant performance disparity to be able to cruise up on another person and have the pace to negate the inherent advantage the defending car has... and this is present in all motorsports due to it just being how the physical world works. Same way tires are a factor in any form of motorsports, because having slightly worse tires means you're slower into the corners, through the corners, and even on straights due to how you need traction to actually put that power into the ground.

From September 29 to October 1, 2023, Falun Gong practitioners organized the "Poster Exhibition on the CCP's Organ Harvesting of Living People" at the Industrial Culture Center of Asaka City, Saitama Prefecture.


On the final day of the expo, organizers screened "Human Harvest," a documentary about state-sanctioned harvesting of human organs from living practitioners, including the transplant chain active in China. After viewing the poster exhibition and documentary, people in the audience said they had a deeper understanding of the Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) willingness to commit atrocities and wanted more information about Falun Gong.



The Poster Exhibition "Stop the CCP's Organ Harvesting of Living People" was held at the Asaka City Industrial Culture Center from September 29 to October 1



Screening of "Human Harvest," a documentary about the state-sanctioned harvesting of human organs from living practitioners in China


Spectators shocked by CCP atrocities
In addition to the posters, in a separate room, visitors were able to watch videos detailing the crimes of harvesting human organs from live practitioners in China. People's expressions became solemn after seeing the costumes and some were moved to tears, shocked by the costume that such cruelty could occur.


One woman in her 50s said: "I've never heard of it. It's so cruel. I was so shocked I couldn't speak." Through tears, she asked what she could do to help.


A commenter told him that people could talk to their legislative representatives to get them to pass a law to end crime and that some local councils had passed resolutions that they sent to Congress. The woman said she would share the information with her friends and bring them back when the event resumed.


One teenager said this was the first time she heard about harvesting organs from living people. "It's very sad that so many people had their organs harvested while they were still alive." She wanted to do something to help, so she said she would tell her friends. She also took photos to share online.


A man went to see the poster exhibition with his high school daughter. "I saw the pamphlet that said, 'Silence means being on the side of the persecutors' and I felt I had to come and know the truth." He also said he would bring his friends when the event returned.


A 50-year-old man said, "Thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to know the facts. I didn't know that the CCP was responsible for such evil. I don't think Taiwan should become part of China. I will tell other people I know what I saw it today."
